intro: Acanthocereus tetragonus var. micracanthus, commonly known as the small-spined night bloomer, is a species of cactus native to Mexico. It is characterized by its cylindrical stems that are covered with short, pale spines. The plant produces white, fragrant flowers that bloom at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as bats and moths. It thrives in well-drained soil and requires full sun exposure. Due to its unique appearance and nocturnal blooming habit, it is a popular choice for xeriscaping and desert gardens.

It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and limestone regions. This cactus species is commonly seen in desert scrublands and along the edges of Chihuahuan Desert habitats. It is well adapted to hot, dry climates with minimal rainfall. Due to its unique appearance and hardiness, it is sometimes cultivated in xeriscapic gardens in regions with similar climates.
